Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 06:52AM American_Bedu wrote: Sophie - thanks for the clarification on pallative. I really appreciate all the great feedback about Gemzar and other options.  I have lost track of all the chemo's I've been on over the years.  I remember I've had TAC, abraxane and Halaven with radiation and clinical trials in between.  My body does not respond best to chemo in regards to side effects.  Every chemo (except abraxane) put me in the hospital for a week or more.  In my case, Halaven was the worse in regards to SE. I will certainly keep everyone updated on what I am put on.
Posts.Title: Seeking Data/Input on Women taking Gemcitabine American_Bedu American_Bedu

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 03:11PM American_Bedu wrote: Thanks, Jill. What I was advised is that Gemcitabine is good at keeping the cancer at bay so as not to progress further but unlike other chemos, the cancer or counts are unlikely to go backwards. I've had terrible luck with chemos with all of them putting me in the hospital.  That's why my onc feels that Gemcitabine will be a good option for me; especially as there seem to be no clinical trials open in my general area that are suitable.
Posts.Title: Seeking Data/Input on Women taking Gemcitabine American_Bedu American_Bedu

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 06:48PM American_Bedu wrote: I was on zometa for about one year and the side effects were hard on me - flu like symptoms, stinging bones pains.  As a result my doctor switched me over to Xgeva which is a shot I receive once per month.  I find Xgeva easy to tolerate and without the pain or flu like symptoms experienced with zometa.
Posts.Title: Anyone taking Zometa? mlrosen Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 10:45PM American_Bedu wrote: I am so happy to hear that many of you have had positive results with Halaven.  Last August my doctor tried to put me on it.  I had one dose and ended up in the hospital for two weeks.  It also turned me into a temporary diabetic but then as the Halaven wore off, the diabetes disappeared.  I can say that the one dose did help me for my tumor markers were zero for several months.  Unfortunately now I have to get back on some kind of aggressive treatment since the ugly cancer has again reared its head and the tumor markers have escalated.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 07:50PM American_Bedu wrote: I think I would get a second opinion.  FYI; when I was first diagnosed and subsequently treated, I was put on tamoxifin.  Turned out my body was resistant to tamoxifin.
Posts.Title: Chemo or no chemo? kayrnic kayrnic

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 10:58PM American_Bedu wrote: I was treated two weeks ago with stereotactic radiation for brain mets.  The brain mets were initially detected by a standard MRI but my doctor then sent me to a specialist for the stereotactic radiation.  At that time I learned there is another MRI which can take a 3 dimensional image of the brain and "slices" sectors of the brain into fine pieces to ensure that all brain mets are detected and also necessary for the planning and staging of the stereotactic radiation.  The specialist told me that some brain mets can go unseen on a standard MRI.  He said once having had brain mets, it is impertative to have routine follow up specialized MRI's rather than the standard MRI. I'm in Charlotte, NC and received the treatment for stereotactic radiation at Carolina's Medical Center, Levine Cancer Institute by Dr. Stuart Burri.
Posts.Title: Brain mets detection bhd1 LuvRVing

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 10:39PM American_Bedu wrote: Consider yourself getting a warm and supportive hug from a virtual sister. I know that some family members simply do not know how to cope with a loved one who has been diagnosed with a terminal disease.  They are so fearful of losing you that they withdraw instead of drawing close.  My advice would be to let her know that you want, need and appreciate whatever support she is able to give.  Let her know how much she and the relationship between you mean to her.  In addition, reach out to your virtual sisters as well as local support groups.  You may find it easier to let out your fears and frustrations with other sisters who are walking in your shoes already. Virtual hugs, Carol
Posts.Title: My sister has completely abandoned me :( rosasmommy Lauriesh

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 09:56PM American_Bedu wrote: Ask your oncologist.  He may want to have you undertake some PT.  Also, check out www.livestrong.org and see if you can get registered in the FREE 8 week livestrong program for cancer patients.  It is a program tailored to rebuilding strength and muscle. I've had bone mets since 2010 and have been given at various intervals radiation, zometa, fosoldex, xgevia.  I no longer take zometa since it gave me more pain. I also take calcium supplements but always ask your doctor first before adding anything to your daily regime. Best Regards, Carol
Posts.Title: anyone else have mets to spine? nikibird SusanR
